qas.question: Who did the Tories occasionally cooperate with?
When did the Tories regain power?
For how long were the Tories dismissed from office?
Why could the Tories and the Opposition Whigs never form a single party?
When was the downfall of George II?
For how long was Lord Bute dismissed from office?
What type of behavior was Lord Bute known for when in power?
What did differing beliefs prevent Lord Bute and George II from doing?
What did Sir William Wyndham regain in 1760?

context: Although the Tories were dismissed from office <b6_0>for <a3_0>half a century<b6_0/><a3_0/>, for most of this period (at first under the leadership of Sir William Wyndham), the Tories retained party cohesion, with occasional hopes of regaining office, particularly at the accession of George II (1727) and the downfall of the ministry of Sir Robert Walpole in <b5_0>1742<b5_0/>. They acted as a united, though unavailing, opposition to Whig <b7_0>corruption and scandals<b7_0/>. At times they cooperated with <a1_0>the "Opposition <a0_0>Whigs<a0_0/>"<a1_0/>, Whigs who were in opposition to the Whig government; however, the <a4_0>ideological gap<a4_0/> between the Tories and the Opposition Whigs prevented them from <b8_0>coalescing as a single party<b8_0/>. They finally regained <b9_0>power<b9_0/> with the accession of George III in <a2_0>1760<a2_0/> under Lord Bute.
